posts.title: About me
posts.markdown:
My name is Ladislas, I was born May 16, 1988.

I've always wanted to be many things in my life. Currently I'm a young biotech engineer, passionnate about robotics, ai and h/r interaction, especially applications for exceptional children.

I'm also cofounder and ceo at [Leka](http://weareleka.com).

We are currently developing [Moti](http://discovermoti.com), a sphericle robotic smart toy for children with behavior, communication and social interactions disabilities. More than a toy, Moti is also a work-in-progress medical device that will help parents and specialists take care of the children in a smarter and more connected way.

If you want to say hi, feel free to email me @ ladislas[at]weareleka.com

You can also find me on [Linkedin](fr.linkedin.com/pub/ladislas-de-toldi/24/101/832/en) and [Github](https://github.com/ladislas).

posts.title: Setting up nvm, node & npm on OS X Mavericks
posts.markdown:
Like any good developer, I use [Homebrew](http://brew.sh/) to manage my softwares, compilers, and so on. I've also been using the `brew` installation of `node` and `npm` for quite sometimes now.

But every time I tried to update all the packages installed globally with `npm`, I had the same error saying that `npm` could not update itself.

Some research on Google brought me to [issue #22408](https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew/issues/22408). As you can see, this bug is quite common and even if there are different mildly working workarounds...

>"...Package managers managing package managers rarely works out well..." - [janv](https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew/issues/22408#issuecomment-28986117)

I first tried installing `node` `--whithout-npm`, but I found out that I don't really like partial management as I often forget what I need to install when setting up a new machine, `npm` in that case...

Until...

## Node Version Manager

For those familiar with Ruby, it is highly recommended to use a Ruby Version Manager such as [rbenv](https://github.com/sstephenson/rbenv) or [rvm](https://rvm.io/). It works like a charm when you need to manage different versions of Ruby and/or don't want to screw up the system version of Ruby.

It turns out that something similar exists for `node`! It is called [`nvm`](https://github.com/creationix/nvm) for *Node Version Manager*. The good news is that you **can** install `nvm` using `brew` which is exactly what I needed!

So let's get started !

First, pull the latest version of `brew` by running:

```
$ brew update && brew upgrade
```

Then, we simply need to install `nvm`:

```
$ brew install nvm
```

Finally, we need to add the following line to our `.profile`, `.bashrc` or `.zshrc`, to be able to run `nvm` from the command line:

```
$ echo "source $(brew --prefix nvm)/nvm.sh" >> ~/.zshrc
```

And that's it!

## Installing node & npm

Installing `nvm` is not enough, we now need to install `node` & `npm`.

To print out the list of all the available versions of node, simply run:

```
$ nvm ls-remote
```

We want to install the current stable version which is v0.10.26, so we need to run:

```
$ nvm install -s v0.10.26
```

The `-s` flag means we want to compile `node` from source.

When the installation process is finished, our brand new `node` and `npm` will be installed!

The great thing with `nvm` is that you can use a different version of `node` in each of your shell instances. But if you want to stick to the latest version, you can set it as `default` by running:

```
$ nvm alias default 0.10.26
```

Make sure everything is up and running by typing `node -v && npm -v`.

## Conclusion

That's all folks! You can now manage different versions of `node/npm` without even thinking about it. :)
posts.html:
Like any good developer, I use Homebrew to manage my softwares, compilers, and so on. I've also been using the brew installation of node and npm for quite sometimes now.

But every time I tried to update all the packages installed globally with npm, I had the same error saying that npm could not update itself.

Some research on Google brought me to issue #22408. As you can see, this bug is quite common and even if there are different mildly working workarounds...

"...Package managers managing package managers rarely works out well..." - janv

I first tried installing node --whithout-npm, but I found out that I don't really like partial management as I often forget what I need to install when setting up a new machine, npm in that case...

Until...

Node Version Manager

For those familiar with Ruby, it is highly recommended to use a Ruby Version Manager such as rbenv or rvm. It works like a charm when you need to manage different versions of Ruby and/or don't want to screw up the system version of Ruby.

It turns out that something similar exists for node! It is called nvm for Node Version Manager. The good news is that you can install nvm using brew which is exactly what I needed!

So let's get started !

First, pull the latest version of brew by running:

$ brew update && brew upgrade

Then, we simply need to install nvm:

$ brew install nvm

Finally, we need to add the following line to our .profile, .bashrc or .zshrc, to be able to run nvm from the command line:

$ echo "source $(brew --prefix nvm)/nvm.sh" >> ~/.zshrc

And that's it!

Installing node & npm

Installing nvm is not enough, we now need to install node & npm.

To print out the list of all the available versions of node, simply run:

$ nvm ls-remote

We want to install the current stable version which is v0.10.26, so we need to run:

$ nvm install -s v0.10.26

The -s flag means we want to compile node from source.

When the installation process is finished, our brand new node and npm will be installed!

The great thing with nvm is that you can use a different version of node in each of your shell instances. But if you want to stick to the latest version, you can set it as default by running:

$ nvm alias default 0.10.26

Make sure everything is up and running by typing node -v && npm -v.

Conclusion

That's all folks! You can now manage different versions of node/npm without even thinking about it. :)

posts.title: Setting up nvm, node & npm on Ubuntu
posts.markdown:
In my [previous post](http://nothingtodisplay.org/setting-up-nvm-node-npm-on-os-x-mavericks/), I explained how to install `node` and `npm` on OS X Mavericks using `nvm`.

We are now going to take a look at how to do the same on Linux.

>**Note:** This procedure has been tested on Ubuntu 14.04 LTS but it should also work for different versions of Linux.

I have a [Windows Azure](http://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/) virtual machine running Ubuntu 14.04 to host different websites and webapps. The idea is that, like me, you might want to use different versions of `node` for different appas. But using `apt-get install nodejs` will only give you the latest version.

Unless...

## Node Version Manager

For those familiar with Ruby, it is highly recommended to use a Ruby Version Manager such as [rbenv](https://github.com/sstephenson/rbenv) or [rvm](https://rvm.io/). It works like a charm when you need to manage different version of Ruby and don't want to screw up the system version of Ruby.

It turns out that something similar exists for `node`! It is called [`nvm`](https://github.com/creationix/nvm) for *Node Version Manager*. The good news is that it is really easy to install!

So let's get started!

First, we need to clone the `nvm` [repository](https://github.com/creationix/nvm):

```
$ git clone https://github.com/creationix/nvm.git ~/.nvm
```

Then, we need to add the following line to our `.profile`, `.bashrc` or `.zshrc`:

```
$ echo "source ~/.nvm/nvm.sh" >> .zshrc
```

This allows us to use `nvm` in your shell. And that's it!

## Installing node & npm

Installing `nvm` is not enough, we now need to install `node` & `npm`.

To print out the list of all the available versions, simply run:

```
$ nvm ls-remote
```

We want to install the current stable version which is v0.10.26, so we need to run:

```
$ nvm install -s v0.10.26
```

The `-s` flag means we want to compile `node` from source.

When the installation process is finished, our brand new `node` and `npm` will be installed!

The great thing with `nvm` is that you can use a different version of `node` in each of your shell instances. But if you want to stick to the latest version, you can set it as `default` by running:

```
$ nvm alias default 0.10.26
```

Make sure everything is up and running by typing `node -v && npm -v`.

## Conclusion

That's all folks! You can now manage different versions of `node/npm` without even thinking about it. :)
posts.html:

We are now going to take a look at how to do the same on Linux.

Note: This procedure has been tested on Ubuntu 14.04 LTS but it should also work for different versions of Linux.

I have a Windows Azure virtual machine running Ubuntu 14.04 to host different websites and webapps. The idea is that, like me, you might want to use different versions of node for different appas. But using apt-get install nodejs will only give you the latest version.

Unless...

Node Version Manager

For those familiar with Ruby, it is highly recommended to use a Ruby Version Manager such as rbenv or rvm. It works like a charm when you need to manage different version of Ruby and don't want to screw up the system version of Ruby.

So let's get started!

To print out the list of all the available versions, simply run:

$ nvm ls-remote

We want to install the current stable version which is v0.10.26, so we need to run:

The -s flag means we want to compile node from source.

When the installation process is finished, our brand new node and npm will be installed!

The great thing with nvm is that you can use a different version of node in each of your shell instances. But if you want to stick to the latest version, you can set it as default by running:

$ nvm alias default 0.10.26

Make sure everything is up and running by typing node -v && npm -v.

Conclusion

That's all folks! You can now manage different versions of node/npm without even thinking about it. :)

posts.title: Accessing Azure Storage from CLI
posts.markdown:
When working on OS X and Linux, you need to use the `azure-cli` to manage your account, vm, storage, websites, etc.

## Installing the Azure Command Line Interface

Installing the `azure-cli` is pretty easy. You can simply run:

```
$ npm install -g azure-cli
```

## Downloading your credentials

To connect to your Azure profile, you need to download your credentials from the Azure website and then import them. Simply run the following:

```
$ azure account download
```

and then:

```
$ azure import /path/to/where/you/downloaded/the/file
```

Now that your credentials are set, you can easily manage your virtual machines, starting, stopping or restarting them.

## Accessing your storage account

But if your try to access your storage account...

```
$ azure storage container list
```

...things become tricky and you might get an error like this one:

![](http://i.imgur.com/fxLHuL1.png)

For security reasons, Azure doesn't want your to use your credentials to access your storage accounts.

That's why you need to provide your `AZURE_STORAGE_ACCOUNT` and your `AZURE_STORAGE_ACCESS_KEY` as `environment variables`.

The best way to do so is to run:

```
$ export AZURE_STORAGE_ACCOUNT=myAzureStorageAccount
$ export AZURE_STORAGE_ACCESS_KEY=myAzureStorageAccessKey
```

It might be cumbersome to do that each time you need to manage your containers and blobs but it might be the only way if you have different storage accounts.

Also, if you use git and a public repo to manage your `.dotfiles`, **it is important that you do *not* include** those two lines inside your `.profile`, `.bashrc` or `.zshrc` because you don't want anyone accessing your storage!

But your could source another **non-git-tracked file**.
posts.html:
When working on OS X and Linux, you need to use the azure-cli to manage your account, vm, storage, websites, etc.

Installing the Azure Command Line Interface

Installing the azure-cli is pretty easy. You can simply run:

$ npm install -g azure-cli

Downloading your credentials

To connect to your Azure profile, you need to download your credentials from the Azure website and then import them. Simply run the following:

$ azure account download

and then:

$ azure import /path/to/where/you/downloaded/the/file

Now that your credentials are set, you can easily manage your virtual machines, starting, stopping or restarting them.

Accessing your storage account

But if your try to access your storage account...

$ azure storage container list

...things become tricky and you might get an error like this one:

For security reasons, Azure doesn't want your to use your credentials to access your storage accounts.

That's why you need to provide your AZURE_STORAGE_ACCOUNT and your AZURE_STORAGE_ACCESS_KEY as environment variables.

The best way to do so is to run:

$ export AZURE_STORAGE_ACCOUNT=myAzureStorageAccount
$ export AZURE_STORAGE_ACCESS_KEY=myAzureStorageAccessKey

It might be cumbersome to do that each time you need to manage your containers and blobs but it might be the only way if you have different storage accounts.

Also, if you use git and a public repo to manage your .dotfiles, it is important that you do not include those two lines inside your .profile, .bashrc or .zshrc because you don't want anyone accessing your storage!

But your could source another non-git-tracked file.

posts.title: Setting up Nginx + Node.js + Express.js
posts.markdown:
Ever since I started using [Nginx](http://nginx.org) as a web server and reverse proxy, I really fell in love with its ease of use and flexibility.

Lately, I wanted to dive deeper into [Node.js](http://nodejs.org/) and [Express.js](http://expressjs.com/) and tried to apply all of this to our [discovermoti.com](http://discovermoti.com) website, hosted on our - lovely - Windows Azure Virtual Machine.

But setting Nginx with Node wasn't as straight forward as I thought...

## Setting up your local Node server

The first thing you need is setting up your Node server.

Without going into the details of the Express app.

posts.title: SSH Connection - Keep it alive, man!
posts.markdown:
As I've been upgrading this blog with the last version of `Node.js`, [Ghost](https://github.com/tryghost/Ghost) and the [Readium theme](https://github.com/starburst1977/readium), I found it utterly frustating to have the `ssh` connection cut off after a minute spent reading some documentation...

Hopefully, there's an easy solution to make your ssh connection last 'till you're done with your work.

Open a new `Terminal` window and do the following:

```bash
# go to your ssh directory
$ cd $HOME/.ssh

# if not already there, create a config file
$ touch config

# open the config file
$ vim config

```

Then, just add the following line:

```
ServerAliveInterval 30
ServerAliveCountMax 240
```

Save and quit. Close and reopen the `Terminal` for the changes to take effect.

*Explanation:*

*	`ServerAliveInterval` is the delay between two `noop` operations to keep the server alive, here 30 seconds
*	`ServerAliveCountMax` is the maximum number of `noop` operations, here 240, which equals to 120 minutes or 2 hours

Hope it helps! :)
posts.html:
As I've been upgrading this blog with the last version of Node.js, Ghost and the Readium theme, I found it utterly frustating to have the ssh connection cut off after a minute spent reading some documentation...

Hopefully, there's an easy solution to make your ssh connection last 'till you're done with your work.

Open a new Terminal window and do the following:

# go to your ssh directory
$ cd $HOME/.ssh

# if not already there, create a config file
$ touch config

# open the config file
$ vim config

Then, just add the following line:

ServerAliveInterval 30  
ServerAliveCountMax 240

Save and quit. Close and reopen the Terminal for the changes to take effect.

Explanation:

  • ServerAliveInterval is the delay between two noop operations to keep the server alive, here 30 seconds
  • ServerAliveCountMax is the maximum number of noop operations, here 240, which equals to 120 minutes or 2 hours

Hope it helps! :)

posts.title: SSH Connection with no password
posts.markdown:
There's plenty of tuts on the internet on how to log to a remote server through ssh without having to type your password each time. For example, this [one](https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-set-up-ssh-keys--2) is very good for beginners! 

Just for me and those who don't remember the commands, here is a summary of what to do...

```bash
# generate key
$ ssh-keygen -t rsa

# press enter to accept and then
$ cat ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub | ssh userName@RemoteServer "mkdir -p ~/.ssh && cat >>  ~/.ssh/authorized_keys"
```

Connect to the remote server and check if the key is there with `cat ~/.ssh/authorized_keys`.

Hope it helps! :)
posts.html:
There's plenty of tuts on the internet on how to log to a remote server through ssh without having to type your password each time. For example, this one is very good for beginners!

Just for me and those who don't remember the commands, here is a summary of what to do...

# generate key
$ ssh-keygen -t rsa

# press enter to accept and then
$ cat ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub | ssh userName@RemoteServer "mkdir -p ~/.ssh && cat >>  ~/.ssh/authorized_keys"

Connect to the remote server and check if the key is there with cat ~/.ssh/authorized_keys.

Hope it helps! :)

posts.title: Customize Zsh and Oh-My-Zsh between OS X and Linux
posts.markdown:
I've been a [Zsh](http://zsh.sourceforge.net/) and [Oh My Zsh](https://github.com/robbyrussell/oh-my-zsh) user for two years now, and I have to say I really love those, my day and my workflow would not be the same without them.

My fork of Robby Russel's Oh My Zsh is available [here](https://github.com/ladislas/oh-my-zsh). I've made some customization:

*	my [`.zshrc`](https://github.com/ladislas/oh-my-zsh/blob/master/templates/zshrcDot.zsh-template) with what we are going to talk about
*	the minimalist-yet-informative [John theme](https://github.com/ladislas/oh-my-zsh/blob/master/themes/john.zsh-theme)
*	custom [`LS_COLORS`](https://github.com/ladislas/oh-my-zsh/tree/master/custom/colors) based on [trapd00r's](https://github.com/trapd00r/LS_COLORS)

Most of the time, I'm working on my Macbook Air with OS X. I also have an old iMac running Ubuntu and the server this blog is running on is also Ubuntu. So setting up Oh My Zsh on both of them was one of the first things I did.

But as my `.zshrc` was for OS X, I had a lot of annoying errors on Ubuntu...

What I did **not** want to do:

*	Having to un/comment the lines between OS X and Ubuntu: it's stupid and as I'm using git it would eventually screw things up...
*	Having to maintain two files:  having to duplicate all the changes is cumbersome and prone to errors...

Comes out the solution I needed was pretty simple: I have to check if the OS running was OS X or Ubuntu. In Zsh language, it goes like that:

```bash
if [[ $OSTYPE =~ "darwin" ]]; then

	echo "Hi Surfer!"
    # Add your OS X configuration here
    
elif [[ $OSTYPE == "linux-gnu" ]]; then

	echo "Hi Hacker!"
    # Add your Linux configuration here
   
fi
```

The important part is `$OSTYPE =~ "darwin"` - note the `=~`, it means we check if `$OSTYPE` contains `darwin`. This way, it works with all the current versions of OS X, from Lion to Yosemite.

If you want to check for a specific version of OS X, you can use `==`, i.e. `$OSTYPE == "darwin14.0.0"` for Yosemite.

You can checkout my own configuration [line 76 in my `.zshrc`](https://github.com/ladislas/oh-my-zsh/blob/master/templates/zshrcDot.zsh-template#L76) as it might be helpful.

As I said, it's pretty basic but made my day when I found it.

Hope this helps! :)
posts.html:
I've been a Zsh and Oh My Zsh user for two years now, and I have to say I really love those, my day and my workflow would not be the same without them.

My fork of Robby Russel's Oh My Zsh is available here. I've made some customization:

  • my .zshrc with what we are going to talk about
  • the minimalist-yet-informative John theme
  • custom LS_COLORS based on trapd00r's

Most of the time, I'm working on my Macbook Air with OS X. I also have an old iMac running Ubuntu and the server this blog is running on is also Ubuntu. So setting up Oh My Zsh on both of them was one of the first things I did.

But as my .zshrc was for OS X, I had a lot of annoying errors on Ubuntu...

What I did not want to do:

  • Having to un/comment the lines between OS X and Ubuntu: it's stupid and as I'm using git it would eventually screw things up...
  • Having to maintain two files: having to duplicate all the changes is cumbersome and prone to errors...

Comes out the solution I needed was pretty simple: I have to check if the OS running was OS X or Ubuntu. In Zsh language, it goes like that:

if [[ $OSTYPE =~ "darwin" ]]; then

    echo "Hi Surfer!"
    # Add your OS X configuration here

elif [[ $OSTYPE == "linux-gnu" ]]; then

    echo "Hi Hacker!"
    # Add your Linux configuration here

fi

The important part is $OSTYPE =~ "darwin" - note the =~, it means we check if $OSTYPE contains darwin. This way, it works with all the current versions of OS X, from Lion to Yosemite.

If you want to check for a specific version of OS X, you can use ==, i.e. $OSTYPE == "darwin14.0.0" for Yosemite.

You can checkout my own configuration line 76 in my .zshrc as it might be helpful.

As I said, it's pretty basic but made my day when I found it.

Hope this helps! :)

posts.title: Arduino IDE, a love/hate relationship - Part 1/2
posts.markdown:
# How to move away & start up fresh

[Arduino](arduino.cc) is a wonderful prototyping platform for anyone who wants to learn the basics of electronics and programming.

Ever wanted to blink a led to [*`Hello, World!`*](https://github.com/leachim6/hello-world)? Now [you can](http://arduino.cc/en/tutorial/blink)!

Arduino is a good way to learn how programs and micro-controllers work because it's *bare-metal*: you have to start with the bare minimum and get intellectually and emotionally very close to your hardware.

## Starting with the Arduino IDE

First thing first, when you start using an Arduino board, you must start with the IDE. It will allow you to quickly understand and play with your hardware.

It's an important part of the process to get to know how all of this is working.

## It's getting tight!

As you get to know your hardware, the projects you'll try to build will get bigger, with more and more lines of code, complexity, classes and libraries.

At that moment, you might start to feel like the IDE is a little tight for all your needs. The reasons are obvious:

- no decent syntax checking
- no code completion
- a very strange way to organise projects
- as for `1.0.6`, the old `gcc 4.3` to compile your code (though not true for 1.5.x)
- etc.

To put it in a nutshell, the Arduino IDE is far behind any simple and decent IDE...

> *"Even using `vim` would be easier..."*, you whisper to yourself.

## What you really want & need

You are now wondering how you could use your favorite text editor, be it [SublimeText](), [Emacs]() or [Vim]() or even [Neovim](), to feel at home when working on your Arduino projects...

And gosh! You definitely like the `command line`!

With Winter coming, your Christmas list might look like this:

> Dear Santa Claus,  
> For Christmas this year I would like to...
> 
> - use my favorite editor to edit code
> - have decent syntax checking and code completion to be more efficient
> - use up-to-date tools and compilers such as the brand new `avr-gcc 4.9.2` (so fancy!)
> - compile and upload my code from the `command line`
> - version control my sources with `git` or similar

## Arduino Makefile

Basically, Arduino code is just *wrapped* `C/C++` that could be easily compiled with `Makefile`. Unless you know what you're dealing with, you'd better search for another solution...

The good news is that

posts.title: Customizing Readium, a Ghost theme
posts.markdown:
The theme used for the blog is [Readium](https://github.com/ladislas/readium), beautyfully designed by [Sven Read](http://www.svenread.com/readium-ghost-theme/).

If you need to modify the `.sass` files to change the look of your blog, it's pretty easy.

```bash
# First go to the readium directory
$ cd /path/to/my/blog/content/themes/readium

# Then go to the css directory
$ cd assets/css

# You need to have sass and bourbon installed, if not...
$ gem install sass
$ gem install bourbon

# Then install bourbon's file in the current css directory
$ bourbon install

# Open main.sass and edit the first line:
# - replace @import 'bourbon'
# - with @import 'bourbon/bourbon'
$ vim main.sass

# Finally, we need to compile the new file
$ sass main.sass:main.css
```

Reload your page and you should be good to go!

Hope this helps! :)
posts.html:
The theme used for the blog is Readium, beautyfully designed by Sven Read.

If you need to modify the .sass files to change the look of your blog, it's pretty easy.

# First go to the readium directory
$ cd /path/to/my/blog/content/themes/readium

# Then go to the css directory
$ cd assets/css

# You need to have sass and bourbon installed, if not...
$ gem install sass
$ gem install bourbon

# Then install bourbon's file in the current css directory
$ bourbon install

# Open main.sass and edit the first line:
# - replace @import 'bourbon'
# - with @import 'bourbon/bourbon'
$ vim main.sass

# Finally, we need to compile the new file
$ sass main.sass:main.css

Reload your page and you should be good to go!

Hope this helps! :)

posts.title: Multithreading on Arduino with ChibiOS/RT
Why I left Vim for Neovim
Neovim Setup On OS X Yosemite
AVR Toolchain with Homebrew & Mac OS X
posts.markdown:
For those of us who love to compile their Arduino code from the `command line`, I've created a `tap` to easily install the AVR Toolchain.

Both `avr-gcc 4.8` and `avr-gcc 4.9` are provided.

Here is the link to the repo:

> [weareleka/homebre-avr](https://github.com/WeAreLeka/homebrew-avr)

## Installing the toolchain

To install the toolchain, is really easy:

```Bash
# First tap the repository
$ brew tap WeAreLeka/avr

# Then to install the latest version of avr-gcc
$ brew install avr-libc

# or to install previous versions of avr-gcc
$ brew install avr-libcXX

# where XX is the version you want to install, eg. 4.8.3
$ brew install avr-libc48
```

## Switching between versions

It is possible to have multiple versions of the AVR Toolchain installed side by side. But they cannot be used at the same time.

To switch between version, for example from `4.9` to `4.8` you need to:

```Bash
# First unlink the current 4.9 version
$ brew unlink avr-gcc avr-libc

# Then link the 4.8 version
$ brew link avr-gcc48 avr-libc48
```

And to switch from an older version to the latest version:

```Bash
# Unlink the current version where XX is the version number
$ brew unlink avr-gccXX avr-libcXX

# Then link the latest version
$ brew link avr-gcc avr-libc
```

Hope it helps! :)

To switch between version, for example from 4.9 to 4.8 you need to:

$ brew unlink avr-gcc avr-libc

# Then link the 4.8 version
$ brew link avr-gcc48 avr-libc48

And to switch from an older version to the latest version:

# Unlink the current version where XX is the version number
$ brew unlink avr-gccXX avr-libcXX

# Then link the latest version
$ brew link avr-gcc avr-libc

Hope it helps! :)

posts.title: Homebrew - How to know if a formula is linked
posts.markdown:
As I've been working on my new [Commitfie](https://github.com/Commitfie) project, I stumbled upon a very basic issue regarding [`brew`](brew.sh)...

> How do you know if a formula is linked or not?

The first idea I got was to use `brew ls --version name_of_formula`.

But this does not tell you if the formula is linked or not. In fact it will return `true` if the formula is just installed and not linked. Try the following code:

```bash
if $(brew ls --version name_of_formula &> /dev/null) ; then
	echo "Yeah\! It is installed\!"
else
	echo "Nooo... it is not installed..."
fi
```

So there might be something else...

> But what's the difference between a `linked formula` and an `unlinked formula`?

Well it's pretty easy: a `linked formula` will be symlinked in `$(brew --prefix)/bin`. So we should be able to call `$ name_of_formula --help` or `$ name_of_formula --version`.

If we get something, it means the formula is linked. Try the following code:

```bash
if $(name_of_formula --help &> /dev/null) ; then
	echo "Yeah\! It is installed\!"
else
	echo "Nooo... it is not installed..."
fi
```

**Important note**: Sometimes, `--help` won't work, neither will `--version`. You should try other options such as `-h`, `-v`, etc. and find the one working for your formula.

> And what if I want to check for formulae in batch?!

The fact that not all formulae use `--help` or `--version` makes it difficult to check for installed formulae in batch...

The other difference between a `linked formula` and an `unlinked formula` is the fact one will be present in `$(brew --prefix)/bin` while the other will not.

We could then list all the formulae in `$(brew --prefix)/bin` and grep the names of the ones we are looking for. Something like that:

```shell
ls -al $(brew --prefix)/bin | grep "name_of_formula"
```

As you can see, it would be really easy to store different `name_of_formula` in a `FORMULA_ARRAY=( formula1 formula1 formula3 )` array and iteralte through it.

So might that be it? The real solution?

Try the following code

```shell
# Make sure all the brew dependencies are met
# You can change the names with your own formulae
BREW_DEPS=( imagesnap imagemagick whereami )
MISSING_BREW_DEPS=()

echo "\nChecking for \`brew\` dependencies:\n "
for dep in "${BREW_DEPS[@]}"
do
	if ls -al $(brew --prefix)/bin | grep "$dep" &> /dev/null ; then
		echo "Looking for $dep........ OK"
	else
		echo "Looking for $dep........ Error, not found!"
		MISSING_BREW_DEPS+=( $dep )
	fi
done

if [  ${#MISSING_BREW_DEPS[@]} -gt 0 ] ; then
	echo "\nThe following brew dependencies are missing: $MISSING_BREW_DEPS...\nYou must install them to continue the installation process..."
	exit 1
else
	echo "All the dependencies are met, you can safely continue the process :)"
fi
```

And that's it! You now can easily check if several formulae are linked and ready to be used.

Hope this helps! :)
posts.html:
As I've been working on my new Commitfie project, I stumbled upon a very basic issue regarding brew...

How do you know if a formula is linked or not?

The first idea I got was to use brew ls --version name_of_formula.

But this does not tell you if the formula is linked or not. In fact it will return true if the formula is just installed and not linked. Try the following code:

if $(brew ls --version name_of_formula &> /dev/null) ; then  
    echo "Yeah\! It is installed\!"
else  
    echo "Nooo... it is not installed..."
fi

So there might be something else...

But what's the difference between a linked formula and an unlinked formula?

Well it's pretty easy: a linked formula will be symlinked in $(brew --prefix)/bin. So we should be able to call $ name_of_formula --help or $ name_of_formula --version.

If we get something, it means the formula is linked. Try the following code:

if $(name_of_formula --help &> /dev/null) ; then  
    echo "Yeah\! It is installed\!"
else  
    echo "Nooo... it is not installed..."
fi

Important note: Sometimes, --help won't work, neither will --version. You should try other options such as -h, -v, etc. and find the one working for your formula.

And what if I want to check for formulae in batch?!

The fact that not all formulae use --help or --version makes it difficult to check for installed formulae in batch...

The other difference between a linked formula and an unlinked formula is the fact one will be present in $(brew --prefix)/bin while the other will not.

We could then list all the formulae in $(brew --prefix)/bin and grep the names of the ones we are looking for. Something like that:

ls -al $(brew --prefix)/bin | grep "name_of_formula"

As you can see, it would be really easy to store different name_of_formula in a FORMULA_ARRAY=( formula1 formula1 formula3 ) array and iteralte through it.

So might that be it? The real solution?

Try the following code

# Make sure all the brew dependencies are met
# You can change the names with your own formulae
BREW_DEPS=( imagesnap imagemagick whereami )  
MISSING_BREW_DEPS=()

echo "\nChecking for \`brew\` dependencies:\n "  
for dep in "${BREW_DEPS[@]}"  
do  
    if ls -al $(brew --prefix)/bin | grep "$dep" &> /dev/null ; then
        echo "Looking for $dep........ OK"
    else
        echo "Looking for $dep........ Error, not found!"
        MISSING_BREW_DEPS+=( $dep )
    fi
done

if [  ${#MISSING_BREW_DEPS[@]} -gt 0 ] ; then  
    echo "\nThe following brew dependencies are missing: $MISSING_BREW_DEPS...\nYou must install them to continue the installation process..."
    exit 1
else  
    echo "All the dependencies are met, you can safely continue the process :)"
fi

And that's it! You now can easily check if several formulae are linked and ready to be used.

Hope this helps! :)

posts.title: Python - Get current working directory path & name
posts.markdown:
This is a friendly reminder for myself as I keep forgetting how simple stuff like that work...

So here we go !

To get the Current Working Directory (`cwd`), i.e, the directory from where you are calling a script (*and **not** the directory where the script is...*), you can just do...

```python
import os
cwd_full_path = os.getcwd()
cwd_dir_name = os.path.basename(cwd_full_path)
```

And you're good to go :)
posts.html:
This is a friendly reminder for myself as I keep forgetting how simple stuff like that work...

So here we go !

To get the Current Working Directory (cwd), i.e, the directory from where you are calling a script (and not the directory where the script is...), you can just do...

import os  
cwd_full_path = os.getcwd()  
cwd_dir_name = os.path.basename(cwd_full_path)

And you're good to go :)

posts.title: Vim, Pandoc, Markdown: Setting up your toolchain
posts.markdown:
If you happen to be using [`Vim/Neovim`](https://github.com/neovim/neovim) and also happen to be writing a lot of Markdown files, then, there are two or three things you might want to know...

## Pandoc Markdown

### What is it?

From the [Pandoc documentation](http://johnmacfarlane.net/pandoc/):

> Pandoc is a Haskell library for converting from one markup format to another, and a command-line tool that uses this library.

So basically, you can use markdown to write close to everything and then transform your file to the desired format using Pandoc. It's as simple as that:

```bash
# convert markdown to .docx
$ pandoc -sS myMarkdownFile.md -o myDocxFile.docx --latex-engine=xelatex

# or from markdown to .pdf
$ pandoc -sS myMarkdownFile.md -o myPdfFile.pdf --latex-engine=xelatex
```

### How to install?

The [Installation page](http://johnmacfarlane.net/pandoc/installing.html) is full of detailed instruction.

If you are on OS X  and use [Homebrew](http://brew.sh/) and [Homebrew Cask](https://github.com/caskroom/homebrew-cask), you can:

```bash
# install mactex for pdf output
$ brew cask install mactex

# install pandoc
$ brew install pandoc
```

## Vim plugins

So now that you are convinced you can use markdown in you day to day life, how can you make your life easier?
posts.html:

Pandoc Markdown

What is it?

From the Pandoc documentation:

Pandoc is a Haskell library for converting from one markup format to another, and a command-line tool that uses this library.

So basically, you can use markdown to write close to everything and then transform your file to the desired format using Pandoc. It's as simple as that:

# convert markdown to .docx
$ pandoc -sS myMarkdownFile.md -o myDocxFile.docx --latex-engine=xelatex

# or from markdown to .pdf
$ pandoc -sS myMarkdownFile.md -o myPdfFile.pdf --latex-engine=xelatex

How to install?

The Installation page is full of detailed instruction.

If you are on OS X and use Homebrew and Homebrew Cask, you can:

# install mactex for pdf output
$ brew cask install mactex

# install pandoc
$ brew install pandoc

Vim plugins

So now that you are convinced you can use markdown in you day to day life, how can you make your life easier?

posts.title: Vim-Pandoc - How to customize markdown file format
posts.markdown:
In Vim/[Neovim](neovim.org), running `:normal gg=G` will reindent your current file depending on its filetype.

If you have [vim-pandoc](https://github.com/vim-pandoc/vim-pandoc) and [vim-pandoc-syntax](https://github.com/vim-pandoc/vim-pandoc-syntax) installed, calling `:normal gg=G` will in return call:

```bash
$ pandoc -t markdown --reference-links
```

It will:

- format your file to [Pandoc's extended Markdown](http://johnmacfarlane.net/pandoc/README.html#pandocs-markdown)
- use [Setext-style headers](http://johnmacfarlane.net/pandoc/README.html#setext-style-headers) for level 1 and 2
- use reference links, i.e. all your inline links will be referenced at the end of your file

If you want to alter this behavior, you just need to add the following to your [`.vimrc`](https://github.com/ladislas/nvim/blob/master/vimrc#L327):

```viml
let g:pandoc#formatting#equalprg = "pandoc -t markdown --no-wrap --atx-headers"
```

With the following, you'll keep your inline links, won't wrap the lines and use [Atx-style headers](http://johnmacfarlane.net/pandoc/README.html#atx-style-headers)

A lot of other options are available to suit your needs, feel free to take a look at the [full documentation](http://johnmacfarlane.net/pandoc/README.html#general-writer-options).
posts.html:
In Vim/Neovim, running :normal gg=G will reindent your current file depending on its filetype.

If you have vim-pandoc and vim-pandoc-syntax installed, calling :normal gg=G will in return call:

$ pandoc -t markdown --reference-links

It will:

  • format your file to Pandoc's extended Markdown
  • use Setext-style headers for level 1 and 2
  • use reference links, i.e. all your inline links will be referenced at the end of your file

If you want to alter this behavior, you just need to add the following to your .vimrc:

let g:pandoc#formatting#equalprg = "pandoc -t markdown --no-wrap --atx-headers"

With the following, you'll keep your inline links, won't wrap the lines and use Atx-style headers

A lot of other options are available to suit your needs, feel free to take a look at the full documentation.

posts.title: Ghost - Random Blog Cover
posts.markdown:
![](https://unsplash.it/2500/1600/?random)

Choosing the right picture for your blog cover can be one of the most stressful things you'll go through.

If you're like me, you can spend hours on websites such as [Unsplash](https://unsplash.com/) to find ***the*** gem.

And if your mind is as perverted as mine, you'll find yourself wanting to change your blog cover **often**! Like, *twice* a week!

> That's insane! What should we do?!

Search no more friends, I have the solution: We need **great random images**!

Two great guys, [David Marby](http://dmarby.se/) & [Nijiko Yonskai](https://github.com/Nijikokun) have created [Unsplash.it](https://unsplash.it/) to easily get images from [Unsplash.com](https://unsplash.com/).

Here are the steps:

- log into your Ghost blog back office
- navigate to **`Settings`** and then the first vertical tab **`General`**
- scroll until your reach **`Blog Cover`**
- click on the image

![](http://i.imgur.com/1h9Hiyr.png)

- in the up right corner, click the `trash logo`

![](http://imgur.com/avEHgDj.png)

- in the bottom left corner, click the `attach logo`

![](http://imgur.com/Y1a9ekn.png)

- you are now asked to enter the url of the image

![](http://imgur.com/fBlFf2Z.png)

- copy and past the following inside the input box

```
https://unsplash.it/2500/1600/?random
```

![](http://imgur.com/o6IVfLK.png)

- click `save`

> You're done ! 

Now visit your blog and reload to see the cover picture change each time :)
posts.html:
Choosing the right picture for your blog cover can be one of the most stressful things you'll go through.

If you're like me, you can spend hours on websites such as Unsplash to find the gem.

And if your mind is as perverted as mine, you'll find yourself wanting to change your blog cover often! Like, twice a week!

That's insane! What should we do?!

Search no more friends, I have the solution: We need great random images!

Two great guys, David Marby & Nijiko Yonskai have created Unsplash.it to easily get images from Unsplash.com.

Here are the steps:

  • log into your Ghost blog back office
  • navigate to Settings and then the first vertical tab General
  • scroll until your reach Blog Cover
  • click on the image

  • in the up right corner, click the trash logo

  • in the bottom left corner, click the attach logo

  • you are now asked to enter the url of the image

  • copy and past the following inside the input box
https://unsplash.it/2500/1600/?random

  • click save

You're done !

Now visit your blog and reload to see the cover picture change each time :)

posts.title: Mac OS X - Setting Desktop Image from Command Line
posts.markdown:
In OS X Yosemite, setting your Desktop Image from the `Terminal.app` or any other `cli` (`command line interface`) is as easy as...

```shell
sqlite3 ~/Library/Application\ Support/Dock/desktoppicture.db "update data set value = '/path/to/your/image.jpg'" && killall Dock
```

This can be made into a function you can add to your `.profile`, `.bashrc`, `.zshrc`, and so on...

```shell
function setDesktopImage() {
	sqlite3 ~/Library/Application\ Support/Dock/desktoppicture.db "update data set value = '$1'" && killall Dock
}
```

You can then call the function like this:

```bash
$ setDesktopImage ~/path/to/your/image.jpg
```
posts.html:
In OS X Yosemite, setting your Desktop Image from the Terminal.app or any other cli (command line interface) is as easy as...

sqlite3 ~/Library/Application\ Support/Dock/desktoppicture.db "update data set value = '/path/to/your/image.jpg'" && killall Dock

This can be made into a function you can add to your .profile, .bashrc, .zshrc, and so on...

function setDesktopImage() {  
    sqlite3 ~/Library/Application\ Support/Dock/desktoppicture.db "update data set value = '$1'" && killall Dock
}

You can then call the function like this:

$ setDesktopImage ~/path/to/your/image.jpg

posts.title: Homebrew - brew upgrade - Error: invalid byte sequence in UTF-8
posts.markdown:
It's been two weeks now that I can't `brew upgrade` my packages on my Macbook Air with OS X Yosemite installed.

I've tried various solutions but nothing worked out...

The strange thing is that all the other commands work perfectly!

```shell
# ladislas @LadBookAir.local in ~
→ brew update
Already up-to-date.

# ladislas @LadBookAir.local in ~
→ brew doctor
Your system is ready to brew.

# ladislas @LadBookAir.local in ~
→ brew upgrade
Error: invalid byte sequence in UTF-8
Please report this bug:
    http://git.io/brew-troubleshooting
/usr/local/Library/Homebrew/vendor/okjson.rb:265:in `match'
/usr/local/Library/Homebrew/vendor/okjson.rb:265:in `numtok'
/usr/local/Library/Homebrew/vendor/okjson.rb:254:in `tok'
/usr/local/Library/Homebrew/vendor/okjson.rb:214:in `lex'
/usr/local/Library/Homebrew/vendor/okjson.rb:45:in `decode'
/usr/local/Library/Homebrew/utils/json.rb:10:in `load'
/usr/local/Library/Homebrew/tab.rb:34:in `from_file'
/usr/local/Library/Homebrew/tab.rb:43:in `for_keg'
/usr/local/Library/Homebrew/cmd/outdated.rb:28:in `block (2 levels) in outdated_brews'
/usr/local/Library/Homebrew/cmd/outdated.rb:22:in `each'
/usr/local/Library/Homebrew/cmd/outdated.rb:22:in `block in outdated_brews'
/usr/local/Library/Homebrew/cmd/outdated.rb:19:in `map'
/usr/local/Library/Homebrew/cmd/outdated.rb:19:in `outdated_brews'
/usr/local/Library/Homebrew/cmd/upgrade.rb:9:in `upgrade'
/usr/local/Library/brew.rb:135:in `<main>'
```

Another interestind thing is that if I call `brew upgrade <name of formula>` it works seemlessly.

I'm going to do a `clean install` anyway in two weeks, but for those having the same issue who need a workaround, here is a simple solution:

```shell
# create an array with all your installed formulae
$ installed_formulae=($(brew list -1))

# try to `brew upgrade` each formula from the array
$ for formula in "${installed_formulae[@]}" ; do brew upgrade $formula ; done
```

The output will look like that:  
![Imgur](http://i.imgur.com/xUVHARz.png)

Hope this helps! :)
posts.html:
It's been two weeks now that I can't brew upgrade my packages on my Macbook Air with OS X Yosemite installed.

I've tried various solutions but nothing worked out...

The strange thing is that all the other commands work perfectly!

# ladislas @LadBookAir.local in ~
→ brew update
Already up-to-date.

# ladislas @LadBookAir.local in ~
→ brew doctor
Your system is ready to brew.

# ladislas @LadBookAir.local in ~
→ brew upgrade
Error: invalid byte sequence in UTF-8  
Please report this bug:  
    http://git.io/brew-troubleshooting
/usr/local/Library/Homebrew/vendor/okjson.rb:265:in `match'

/usr/local/Library/Homebrew/vendor/okjson.rb:45:in `decode'
/usr/local/Library/Homebrew/utils/json.rb:10:in `load'
/usr/local/Library/Homebrew/tab.rb:34:in `from_file'
/usr/local/Library/Homebrew/tab.rb:43:in `for_keg'
/usr/local/Library/Homebrew/cmd/outdated.rb:28:in `block (2 levels) in outdated_brews'

$ for formula in "${installed_formulae[@]}" ; do brew upgrade $formula ; done

posts.title: Downloading Adobe Creative Cloud Apps without an Adobe ID
posts.markdown:
As an Adobe user, you might sometimes need to download one of the app of the Creative Cloud such as Illustrator or InDesign. Or you might just want to try them for 30 days before subscribing to the paid membership.

## The old way - Adobe ID, cookies & wasted time

Briefly: you need to create and Adobe ID, connect to the Adobe website, start downloading the Lightroom trial to activate the cookies, stop the download and then copy pas one of the links provided by [ProDesignTools](http://prodesigntools.com/adobe-cc-2014-direct-download-links.html).

As you can imagine, this takes a lot of time and is really cumbersome...

Hopefully, we might have an alternative!

## The new way - Command line power

The easiest way to download the apps is to simply use the [`brew`](brew.sh) version of `wget`.

So just open the `Terminal.app` and type:

```shell
$ wget --header="Cookie: MM_TRIALS=1" <link to the app>
```

It will download the file in your `Home` folder.

## All the links

To make it easier for you, here are all the links you need:

```shell
wget --header="Cookie: MM_TRIALS=1" http://prodesigntools.com/trials3/AdobeProducts/PHSP/15/osx10/Photoshop_15_LS20.dmg

wget --header="Cookie: MM_TRIALS=1" http://prodesigntools.com/trials3/AdobeProducts/ILST/18/osx10-64/Illustrator_18_LS20.dmg

wget --header="Cookie: MM_TRIALS=1" http://prodesigntools.com/trials3/AdobeProducts/IDSN/10/osx10/InDesign_10_LS20.dmg

wget --header="Cookie: MM_TRIALS=1" http://prodesigntools.com/trials3/AdobeProducts/AICY/10/osx10/InCopy_10_LS20.dmg

wget --header="Cookie: MM_TRIALS=1" http://prodesigntools.com/trials3/AdobeProducts/DRWV/14/osx10/Dreamweaver_14_LS20.dmg
```

posts.html:
As an Adobe user, you might sometimes need to download one of the app of the Creative Cloud such as Illustrator or InDesign. Or you might just want to try them for 30 days before subscribing to the paid membership.

The old way - Adobe ID, cookies & wasted time

Briefly: you need to create and Adobe ID, connect to the Adobe website, start downloading the Lightroom trial to activate the cookies, stop the download and then copy pas one of the links provided by ProDesignTools.

As you can imagine, this takes a lot of time and is really cumbersome...

Hopefully, we might have an alternative!

The new way - Command line power

The easiest way to download the apps is to simply use the brew version of wget.

So just open the Terminal.app and type:

$ wget --header="Cookie: MM_TRIALS=1" <link to the app>

It will download the file in your Home folder.

All the links

To make it easier for you, here are all the links you need:

wget --header="Cookie: MM_TRIALS=1" http://prodesigntools.com/trials3/AdobeProducts/PHSP/15/osx10/Photoshop_15_LS20.dmg

posts.title: Git Rebase Local Repository on Remote Origin - Arduino-Makefile
posts.markdown:
I have a fork of [sudar's Arduino-Makefile](https://github.com/sudar/Arduino-Makefile) to which I added [automatic library detection](https://github.com/weareleka/Arduino-Makefile/blob/auto-lib/bin/lib-detection) during compilation to use for [Leka](http://leka.io) and the [Bare-Arduino-Project](https://github.com/ladislas/Bare-Arduino-Project).

I try to keep up-to-date with their changes once in a while before I figure out how to easily merge my changes to their project.

To do that I have to use [`git rebase`](https://git-scm.com/docs/git-rebase) but each time I find myself googling the question and wasting half an hour to figure out the correct process.

To never have to waste time again, here is reminder for my future self, that could be useful for others as well.

```
$ git clone https://github.com/weareleka/Arduino-Makefile
$ git remote add sudar https://github.com/sudar/Arduino-Makefile
$ git fetch sudar
$ git checkout master
$ git reset --hard sudar/master
$ git checkout auto-lib
$ git checkout -b auto-lib-rebase
$ git rebase -X theirs origin/master

```

Hope you liked it! :)
posts.html:
I have a fork of sudar's Arduino-Makefile to which I added automatic library detection during compilation to use for Leka and the Bare-Arduino-Project.

I try to keep up-to-date with their changes once in a while before I figure out how to easily merge my changes to their project.

To do that I have to use git rebase but each time I find myself googling the question and wasting half an hour to figure out the correct process.

To never have to waste time again, here is reminder for my future self, that could be useful for others as well.

$ git clone https://github.com/weareleka/Arduino-Makefile
$ git remote add sudar https://github.com/sudar/Arduino-Makefile
$ git fetch sudar
$ git checkout master
$ git reset --hard sudar/master
$ git checkout auto-lib
$ git checkout -b auto-lib-rebase
$ git rebase -X theirs origin/master

Hope you liked it! :)

posts.title: Update all your pip packages in one command
posts.markdown:
I find it useful sometimes to update all my packages sometimes.

Some might say that it's ~~stupid~~ dangerous to do so and that I should be cherry picking with care what I want to update and why. But I've never had any issues with that.

Package managers such as `gem` and `brew` have those commands built-in:

```shell
# update all your brew packages
$ brew update

# update all your gems
$ gem update
```

But for some reasons, `pip` cannot do that...

To do so you might use the following command, that I stole from [*rbp* on Stackoverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/a/3452888):

```shell
$ pip freeze --local | grep -v '^\-e' | cut -d = -f 1  | xargs -n1 pip install -U
```

It's quite long to type and even harder to remember. So let's make some aliases that your can add to your `.bashrc` or `.zshrc`.

```
alias pip-update="pip freeze --local | grep -v '^\-e' | cut -d = -f 1  | xargs -n1 pip install -U"
alias pip3-update="pip3 freeze --local | grep -v '^\-e' | cut -d = -f 1  | xargs -n1 pip3 install -U"
```

Note the double quotes `"` around the command. That's because `grep` is using single quotes `'` that are not escaped (I find it cleaner/easier to read). I was first getting an error message because of this and it took me a few minutes to figure it out. I'll remember that next time!

If you're like me and using [preszto](https://github.com/ladislas/prezto), I also added those two aliases to the [`python` module](https://github.com/ladislas/prezto/blob/master/modules/python/init.zsh#L53).

Don't forget to activate the module in [`.zpreztorc](https://github.com/ladislas/prezto/blob/master/runcoms/zpreztorc#L43).

Feel free to fork and add you own!

I find it useful sometimes to update all my packages sometimes.

Some might say that it's stupid dangerous to do so and that I should be cherry picking with care what I want to update and why. But I've never had any issues with that.

Package managers such as gem and brew have those commands built-in:

# update all your brew packages
$ brew update

# update all your gems
$ gem update

But for some reasons, pip cannot do that...

To do so you might use the following command, that I stole from rbp on Stackoverflow:

$ pip freeze --local | grep -v '^\-e' | cut -d = -f 1  | xargs -n1 pip install -U

It's quite long to type and even harder to remember. So let's make some aliases that your can add to your .bashrc or .zshrc.

alias pip-update="pip freeze --local | grep -v '^\-e' | cut -d = -f 1  | xargs -n1 pip install -U"  
alias pip3-update="pip3 freeze --local | grep -v '^\-e' | cut -d = -f 1  | xargs -n1 pip3 install -U"

Note the double quotes " around the command. That's because grep is using single quotes ' that are not escaped (I find it cleaner/easier to read). I was first getting an error message because of this and it took me a few minutes to figure it out. I'll remember that next time!

If you're like me and using preszto, I also added those two aliases to the python module.

Don't forget to activate the module in `.zpreztorc.

Feel free to fork and add you own!
